title-group.article-title: Natural sucrose esters: Perspectives on the chemical and physiological use of an under investigated chemical class of compounds

sec.p: Review
Natural sucrose esters: Perspectives on the chemical and physiological use of an under investigated chemical class of compounds

Jorge Andrés Mora Vargas a , Julieth Orduña Ortega a,b , Gustavo Metzker a , Jesus Eliecer Larrahondo b
, Mauricio Boscolo
a,
∗
a São Paulo State University (UNESP), Institute of Biosciences, Humanities and Exact Sciences, São Jose do Rio Preto, SP, Brazil

b
Universidad Santiago de Cali, Facultad de Ciencias Básicas, Campus Pampalinda, Santiago de Cali, Colombia
ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ABSTRACT

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The present review describes the chemistry and physiological properties of the sucrose esters (SEs) obtained from natural or synthetic pathways, with emphasis on those that have aliphatic and phenylpropanoid substituents on their sucrose moiety. Synthesis, extraction and characterization methods for the SEs and NSEs are discussed in terms of synthetic procedures, separation techniques and spectroscopic methods. The physiological properties are discussed taking into account the nature of the substituent groups and their regiochemistry (position and number of substitutions) on the sucrose moiety.

sec.title: 1. Sucrose, sucrose esters (SEs) and natural sucrose esters (NSEs)
sec.p: SEs and NSEs are both characterized by their low toxicity in humans, as well as being environmentally friendly and biodegradable

sec.title: 2. Synthetic methodologies of SEs
sec.p:
Different catalysts have been used in transesterification reaction for the synthesis of SEs. For instance,
determined the influence of potassium carbonate on the production of sucrose caprylate. The results showed that when the amount of catalyst was 13% potassium carbonate in relation to the moles of the starting methyl ester, the yields were 75% higher than those obtained when other catalysts such as monosodium hydrogen phosphate and a mixture of potassium carbonate and polyethylene glycol (PEG-400) were used.

studied the synthesis of laureate sucrose using different catalysts, with sodium bisphosphate finding high selectivity in the production of mono-substituted isomers but low yields in the transesterification reaction. The use of Celite as catalyst provides conversion close to 30% in 24 h, with high selectivity in mono-esters. Disodium hydrogen phosphate (Na 2 HPO 4 )/Celite was employed as catalysts to provide a conversion of 60% to mono-esters and 40% to diesters, with high selectivity for mono-esters directed toward the secondary hydroxyl OH-2 (80%) and OH-3 (20%). Also, it is reported that the use of γ- alumina as catalyst in this reaction caused negligible acylation of sucrose.

Another approach is the combination of homogenous catalysis with acoustic cavitation.
improved the production of mono-substituted SEs by testing different parameters of ultrasonic irradiation in transesterification synthesis with ethyl esters of fatty acids. The authors concluded that mono-substitution (92%) is favored with 2:1 sucrose to methyl ester molar ratio, and that it is possible to achieve reaction rates of up to 73% with selectivity in hydroxyl OH-6 and OH- 6'.

The total synthesis of phenylpropanoid SEs, as reported by
, was from the reaction of 2,1’:4,6-di-
O
-isopropylidene sucrose and p -acetoxyferuloyl chloride, producing tetra-acylated derivative with yields ranging from 30% to 44%. The tetra-acylated derivate were subjected to acetal deprotection using 60% aqueous acetic acid at 80 ̊ C . The products, SEs, were formed by deacetylation reaction with piperidine-95% ethanol ( Fig. 3b ). As presented above, the phenylpropanoid SEs are important classes of natural compounds with different biological activities.

sec.title: 3. Methodology of extraction of NSEs
sec.p:
Another phenylpropanoid NSEs from
Polygonum hydropiper
was extracted by similar methodology by Van
. Briefly, 3.0 kg of leaves and stems were submitted to extraction with hot methanol (three-fold) and the obtained extract ( 0.15 kg ) was suspended in water, and then partitioned with chloroform and n-butanol in that order. The organic phases produced by n-butanol ( 0.02 kg ) and chloroform ( 0.03 kg ) fractions were purified by silica gel column chromatography using a discontinuous gradient of increasing polarity from chloroform, methanol and water, yielding 15–60 mg of NSEs.

employed supercritical fluid for the NSEs extraction from Turkish tobacco. The NSEs were isolated from tobacco leaf ( 2 g ) using supercritical CO 2 at different temperature and pressure (optimal condition: 100% of CO 2 , 100 ̊ C and 250 atm). The products obtained were partitioned with hexane and methanol-water (80%–20%) mixture. The methanol-water fraction was re-extracted using hexane and chloroform. In comparison with conventional extraction methodologies, the use of supercritical fluids decreased the number of stages in the purification and isolation process. However, this method provides similar extraction percentage of NSEs (determinate by GC-MS) when compared to conventional methods. Regarding synthetic SEs purification, this is still a challenge, however, other isolation methods have been commonly used.

sec.title: 4. Characterization of SEs and NSEs
sec.p: The chemical characterization of SEs and NSEs is a challenging task, and this is due to the possible presence of various regioisomers giving rise to a large number of possible structures. On this perspective, the combination of the various techniques such as liquid or gas chromatography (LC or GC, respectively) hyphenated or not with mass spectrometry (MS), and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) are used to elucidate the SEs and NSEs structures.

sec.title: 4.1. Liquid chromatography (LC)
sec.p: The utilization of LC for the isolation of SEs and NSEs employing different system conditions has been studied since it is not necessary to carry out sample derivatization prior to the analysis. Several stationary phases including C 18, C 8 and modified silica-based have been used to perform the regioisomers separation.

Depending on the type of organic acid (aliphatic or aromatic) substituent on the sucrose moiety, the type of detector coupled with LC is chosen. SEs and NSEs substituted with long- or short-chain fatty acids are not usually detected by UV absorption, therefore, detectors such as evaporative light scattering (ELSD), refractive index (RI), charged aerosol detector ( CAD ) and LC-MS are used with the latter used mainly for the identification of SEs and NSEs.

For example,
determined the degree of conversion in the synthesis of sucrose laurate using C 18 column coupled with a RI detector using methanol/water as the mobile phase.
used a silica-based column modified with aminopropyl coupled with a RI detector for the analysis of group migration on the sucrose in the transesterification reaction, and separation of regioisomers produced in the synthesis of aliphatic SEs.

used a C 8 column coupled with ELSD for the identification of SEs with long-chain fatty acid with different degree of substitution using methanol: tetrahydrofuran and water in gradient elution as the mobile phase. Other studies for the separation and identification of commercial aliphatic SEs with different degree of substitution were conducted by
using a C 18 column coupled with ELSD or MS detector using methanol/water as the mobile phase.

Other methodology for the identification of the regioisomeric distribution in mixture of SEs was performed by
using C 8 column coupled with a charged aerosol detector ( CAD ). The separation was carried out using acetonitrile: water as the mobile phase in gradient elution mode. The sucrose ester was dissolved in HCl solution (pH 1.0), and analyzed by LC-CAD. The results revealed the presence of eight regioisomers of sucrose mono-laurate.

identified sucrose 6-acetate synthetized employing the biocatalysis by ESI-LC-MS in positive mode. The result showed a peak of [M + Na] + at m / z 407, and two typical fragment ions, [M– C 6 H 10 O 5 + Na] + at m / z 245 and [M– C 8 H 14 O 7 + Na] + at m/z 185, formed by the glycosidic bond cleavage.

On the other hand,
analyzed 6- and 6′-
O
-lauroyl sucrose regioisomers by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization (MALDI), time-of-flight (TOF) MS, and High-Resolution Mass Spectrometry (HR-MS). The MALDI-TOF-MS showed the signal correspondent for the molecular ion adducts with Na + and K + at m / z 547 and 563, respectively, and was confirmed by HR-MS. Also, in both regioisomers two characteristics signal were found. The first molecular ion is found at m / z 345 and it corresponds to glycosyl fatty acid ester ions [M–Glucose + H ] + or [M–Fructose + H ] + formed by the glycosidic bond cleavage and subsequent loss of C 6 H 12 O 6 in
the sucrose. The second molecular ion is found at m/ z 273 formed by the loss of three CH 2 O molecules in [M–Glucose + H ] + or [M–Fructose + H ] + to form [M– C 9 H 18 O 9 + H ] + . In addition, for 6- O- lauroyl sucrose, two additional signals are found at m / z 439 and 409, corresponding to the ions adducts [M– C 3 H 8 O 4 + Na] + and [M– C 4 H 10 O 5 + Na] + , respectively. The neutral loss of three CH 2 O groups and one H 2 O in the [ C 24 H 44 O 12 + Na] + formed the first molecular ions. Also, the additional loss of one CH 2 O formed the second molecular ion.

In addition, the regioisomeric distribution and structure identification of SEs with different long-chain fatty acids as substituents can be performed by LC-MS.
employed a C 18 column coupled to MS detector with electrospray ionization interface (ESI) for the separation and identification of NSEs extracted from oriental tobacco leaves using methanol/water in gradient of elution.
used mixtures of commercial isomers of sucrose monolaurate, monodecanoate and monopalmitate for the identification of regioisomeric distribution in the sample by LC-ESI-MS. A C 18 column at 40 ̊ C was used as the stationary phase and the SEs eluted in isocratic mode with an acetonitrile-water mixture serving as the mobile phase.

sec.p: 5. Physiological properties of NSEs with aliphatic substitutes

Various plants species have been studied as sources of NSEs containing aliphatic substituents. However,
Physalis spp
,
Nicotiana tabacum (Solanaceae)
,
Equisetum hiemale (Equisetaceae)
and
Vernonia guineensis (Compositae)
are the ones which were extensively investigated in regard to extraction, chemical characterization and physiological effects of NSEs ( Table 1 ).

Different species of the genus
Physalis
from the Solanaceae family are used for the treatment of different diseases such as cancer, urinary problems and hepatitis. For example,
Physalis solanaceus ( Pérez-Castorena et al., 2012 )
,
Physalis peruviana
(
;
),
Physalis alkekengi
var. Franchetiiv
(
,
,
),
Physalis angulata
L (
),
Physalis nicandroides var. Attenuata
(
),
Physalis viscosa ( Ovenden et al., 2005 )
,
Physalis philadelphica ( Zhang et al., 2016b )
and
Physalis sordida ( Pérez-Castorena et al., 2010 )
have been utilized for the treatment of various diseases. Generally, NSEs are extracted from fruits, leaves, aerial parts and calyces of
Physalis spp.
These compounds showed substitutions on the hydroxyl groups of C-2 and C-3’ with long-chain fatty acids such as lauric and capric acid. Also, short-chain fatty acids such as isovaleric, isobutyric, angelic or tiglic and acetic were also found as substituents. The physiological activity of these NSEs were suggest them as anti-inflammatory and antibacterial agents ( Table 1 ) (
;
;
).

Other NSEs found in the fruits of
P. peruviana
( 4 and 5 ) ( Fig. 4 ) contain lauric and capric acids as substituents on the hydroxyl group of the C-2, respectively. Also, these fruits were reported as inhibitors of α- amylase enzymes, which provides the possible explanation for their hypoglycemic effect (
). In addition, in 2018,
extracted eight new NSEs ( 6–13 , Fig. 4 ). These NSEs are characterized by the presence of long-chain fatty acids (8–10 carbon atoms) as substituent on the hydroxyl group of the C-2, and short-chain fatty acid as substituent on the hydroxyl groups of the C-3, C-4, C-6 and C-3’. A crude extract with NSEs ( 6–9 ) was tested as a skin-aging biomarker in a normal aged human dermal fibroblast (NHDF) cell. The result showed cytotoxic activities for this extract at concentrations between 0.02 and 10 mg L −1 . However, 75% living cell threshold was reached at 2 mg L −1 .

NSEs isolated from the aerial parts of
P. alkekengi var. Franchetiiv
( 14–21 , Fig. 5 ) are characterized by different degrees of substitution with saturated and unsaturated carboxylic acids. These compounds have shown antibacterial activity on Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria such as
Staphylococcus aureus
,
Bacillus subtilis
,
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
,
Streptococcus pneumoniae
and
Escherichia coli
, with a minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) between 2 and 15 μg mL −1 (
,
,
). Although not expected, NSE with a long-chain fatty acid containing an odd number of carbons (13 carbons, 3′- O -tridecanoyl-2,3-di- O -tigloylsucrose) was isolated from
P. alkekengi var. franchetiiv ( Zhang et al., 2017 )
.

On the other hand, NSEs substituted with short-chain fatty acids ( 20 and 21 , Fig. 5 ) had less antibacterial activity. However, the 2- O -dodecanoyl-3- O -(2-methyl-2-butenoyl) sucrose extracted from
P. viscosa
( 22 ) ( Fig. 5 ) showed specific antibacterial activity for Gram-positive bacteria such as
S. aureus
and
S. pneumoniae ( Ovenden et al., 2005 )
.

showed that the size of the fatty acid chain influences the inhibitory action of the NSEs. Mono-SEs with stearic (18-C) and palmitic (16-C) acid as substituents did not inhibit Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, whereas, decreasing of the number of carbons of the fatty acid chain increased the antibacterial activity for the sucrose derivatives containing capric (10C), lauric (12C) and myristic acids (14C).

The aliphatic NSEs presented in
P. nicandroides var. attenuata
( 23–26 , Fig. 6 ) were found in higher concentrations in the resin covering the fruits than in other parts of the plant. Although, the specific physiological activity of these NSEs was not determined, it is suggested that these NSEs may act as protective agents to the fruit with insecticidal activity based on similar characteristics exhibited by other NSEs with similar structure (
).

Three mono-NSEs were extracted from
Equisetum hiemale
L. ( Equisetaceae ) ( 35–37 , Fig. 7 ). These sucrose derivatives had substitutions on the hydroxyl group of C-6’ with linolenic, hexadeca- 7,10,13-trienoic or hexadeca-7,10-dienoic acids. The cytotoxicity of these NSEs were tested against cell lines in vitro , however, all the NSEs were inactive (
).

sec.title: 6. Physiological properties of NSEs with phenylpropanoid substitutes
sec.p:
The NSEs from
Phyllanthus cochinchinensis (Phyllanthaceae)
( 41–45, Fig. 8 ) are characterized by the presence of benzoic and cinnamoic acid on the hydroxyl group of C-6 or C-3’, and short-chain fatty acid (acetic acid) on the secondary hydroxyl group of the glucose unit as substituents. These compounds were tested against five human cancer cell lines, however, all the NSEs showed no cytotoxic activity at a concentration of 40 μM (
).

Extracts of
Prunus tomentosa (Rosaceae)
fruits are used in Eastern traditional medicine for their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, and are normally consumed in juices and also used in the manufacture of wines (
). In this extract, 3-phenylpropanoid-triacetyl sucrose esters ( 51–54 , Fig. 9 ) were identified to exhibit antitumor activities in human cancer cells. The NSE ( 53 ) being the compound that attained the highest activity, with IC 50 of 0.11–0.62 μmol L
− 1
in the MCF-7, A 549, HeLa and HT-29 cancer cells. In addition, it has been determined that aliphatic substitutes in sucrose may play an important role in their cytotoxic characteristics, depending on their substitution positions in the molecule (
).

Two polysubstituted NSEs were extracted from
Polygonum lapathifolium (Polygonaceae)
( 55 and 56 , Fig. 9 ). These NSEs have three coumaroyl units as substituents on the hydroxyl groups of C-6, C-1′ and C-3’. Also, the NSEs 55 and 56 showed an additional coumaroyl and feruloyl unit on the hydroxyl group of C-6’, respectively. These NSEs showed inhibitory effects against the promotion stage of the two-stage carcinogenesis induced by TPA , with 90% and more than 60% inhibition at 1000 and 500 mol ratio/ TPA concentration, respectively (
).

Another phenylpropanoid SEs extracted from
Polygonum perfoliatum (Polygonaceae)
( 57–60 , Fig. 9 ) had no reported physiological activity. However, these NSEs are characterized by the presence of two feruloyl units on the hydroxyl groups of C-3′ and C-6’, and the presence of three or four acetyl units as substituents (
).

NSEs derived from dihydronaphthalene lignans ( 61 and 62 , Fig. 10 ), but extracted from
Echium angustifolium (Boraginaceae)
as amorphous powders, are compounds with in vitro anticancer activity in hepatocellular carcinoma (HepG2) and breast cancer (MCF7) cells, with morphological changes in cells treated with the inhibitor leading to IC 50 between 10 and 20 μg mL −1 (
). In comparison with the anticancer activity presented by the NSEs extracted from
Prunus tomentosa
, the NSEs 51–54 displayed higher cytotoxic activities when compared with NSEs 61 and 62 . This better activity can be associated with the presence of acetyl groups on sucrose, and by the increase of the lipophilicity of the NSEs. The latter increases with increasing number of acetyl groups in the molecule (
).

Another p -coumaroyl NSE was identified in species of the genus
Fagopyrum acutatum (Polygonaceae)
( 66 , Fig. 11 ) which also has in its structure a ferulic substitute in the OH-6′ position. Its biological activity was determined by the inhibition of α- amylase, with IC 50 of 26.9 μmol L −1 . The aliphatic NSE extracted from
Physalis peruviana
showed α- amylase inhibition by up to 85% at 640 μg L −1 , however, the authors did not present the IC 50 values. On the other hand, the compound ( 66 ) can be used in the food industry in the control of postprandial hyperglycemia by mitigating the rate of starch digestion in the gastrointestinal tract (
).

Feruloyl SEs ( 71–76, Fig. 12 ) extracted from
Smilax bracteata (Smilacaceae)
showed biological activity as antioxidant agents, however, with moderate activities against 2,2-diphenyl-1-picryl-hydrazyl radical (DPPH). The NSE 71 presents an additional feruloyl unit on C-1′ when compared to other phenylpropanoid SEs ( 73–76 ), and showed higher antioxidant activity (DPPH) which indicates that the substitution degree play a crucial role in their antioxidant activity (
). Another natural phenylpropanoid SEs extracted from
Smilax glabra (Smilacaceae)
( 77–81 , Fig. 12 ), with no physiological activity reported, showed ferulic and coumaric acid as substituents on the hydroxyl group of C-1′, C-3′ and C-6’, and acetic acid on the different free hydroxyl group forming polysubstituted NSEs (Chen et al., 2000).

On the other hand, some natural phenylpropanoid SEs, with no physiological activity reported, were extracted from
Prunus padus (Rosaceae)
( 82–85, Fig. 12 ) (
) and
Aristolochia cretica (Aristolochiaceae)
( 86 and 87, Fig. 12 ) (
). The NSEs ( 82–85 ) has a main structure of 3-
O -p-
coumaroyl sucrose and substituted in different position on the sucrose with acetyl group (short-chain fatty acid), producing natural polysubstituted SEs. In the NSE ( 87 ), the p -coumaroyl group is a substituent in the hydroxyl group on C-6. This SEs can be identified as a regioisomers of ( 46 ).

Natural phenylpropanoid SEs with anti-inflammatory and antitumor activity ( 112–117 , Fig. 15 ) were extracted from the seeds of
Raphanus sativus (Brassicaceae)
, a common vegetable consumed in human diet and use in traditional Chinese medicine. These NSEs were identified as tri- and di-SEs with feruloyl, sinapoyl and 3,4,5-trimethoxycinnamoyl units as substituents on different hydroxyl groups of sucrose. Also, from this specie, the NSEs were extracted ( 93 ) and identified in the plant genus
Polygala
. The isolated NSEs ( 112–117 and 93 ) were investigated in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-activated murine microglia BV-2 cells and tested as inhibitors of the production of nitric oxide ( NO ) (proinflammatory mediator). These NSEs showed anti-inflammatory activity, with IC 50 values <50 μmol L −1
; (
).

Another NSEs with phenylpropanoid substituents ( 118–122 , Fig. 15 ) were isolated from
Calamus quiquesetinervius (Arecaceae)
. These NSEs showed coumaroyl and feruloyl units as substituents mainly on the hydroxyl group of C-3′, C-6’ and/or C-4 with different degree of substitutions, and presents acetyl unit on the hydroxyl group of C-6 or C-2. These NSEs were tested for their anti-inflammatory activity through the inhibition of the production of NO in RAW 264.7 cells. All NSEs demonstrate anti-inflammatory activity, however, NSEs 121 and 122 exhibited inhibition with IC 50 values <10 μmol L −1 . In comparison with the NSEs extracted from
Raphanus sativus
, NSEs 121 and 122 structurally showed acetyl and trans -coumaroyl units on the α- Dglucopyranosyl moiety and lower IC 50 values. Additionally, the NSEs extracted from
Raphanus sativus
and
Calamus quiquesetinervius
showed cytotoxic and antioxidant activities, respectively (
;
).

Two natural phenylpropanoid SEs ( 123 and 124 , Fig. 15 ) were extracted from
Canna edulis Ker Gawl (Cannaceae)
, a plant used in traditional Vietnamese medicine. These NSEs present acetyl and p - coumaroyl units as substituents on the hydroxyl group of C-6 and C-3′, respectively. NSE 123 showed an additional coumaroyl unit as substituent on the hydroxyl group of C-6’, however, NSE 124 presents a feruloyl unit in the same position (
).

sec.title: 7. Conclusion and perspectives
sec.p: The physiological activity of different NSEs has been demonstrated with encouraging results. The nature of the substituent phenylpropanoid or aliphatic group changes the physiological observed effects, giving rise to a wide range of applications of these compounds in many chemical and pharmaceutical fields. For each class of NSEs, the type of organic acid substituents (aliphatic or phenylpropanoid), the substituent position, and the degree of esterification changes the physicochemical proprieties of the NSEs and, consequently, the biological activity. The lower concentration of NSEs makes extraction processes impracticable. This therefore opens a wide field in the development of undescribed chemical synthetic routes for these compounds. However, the reactivity control of sucrose and, principally, the degree and position of the substituents still a challenge.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Jorge Andrés Mora Vargas is graduated in chemistry at Universidad Santiago de Cali , Colombia (2016), M.Sc. (2019) at the São Paulo State University at Institute of Biosciences, Humanities and Exact Sciences (IBILCE), Brazil and Ph.D student in chemistry at same institution under supervision of Prof. M. Boscolo. He was visiting student in the Centro de Investigación y Desarrollo Tecnológico en Electroquímica (CIDETEQ)” Queretaro-Mexico (2016), under supervision of Prof. C . Frontana. His research is focused on sugarcanebased raw chemicals (sucrose, fusel oil and ethanol) to obtain higher added-value compounds.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Julieth Orduña Ortega is graduated in chemistry at Universidad del Valle , Colombia (1999), M.Sc. (2006) at same institution and Ph.D student in chemistry at the São Paulo State University at Institute of Biosciences, Humanities and Exact Sciences (IBILCE), Brazil , under supervision of Prof. M. Boscolo. Her research experience has been developed in the use of advanced oxidation processes for the treatment of chemical residues, the use of biological treatments for the management of organic waste and biomass conversion into more added value products.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Gustavo Metzker is graduated in Chemistry at University of São Paulo , Chemistry Institute of São Carlos (2006), M. Sc. (2009) and Ph.D (2013) in Inorganic Chemistry at same institution. He was postdoctoral fellow at University of São Paulo , Chemistry Institute of São Carlos (2013–2017) under supervision of Prof. A . C . B . Burtoloso with 1-year period at University of California (Santa Barbara) under supervision of Prof. Peter C . Ford. Since 2017 he is postdoctoral fellow at São Paulo State University at Institute of Biosciences, Humanities and Exact Sciences (IBILCE) under supervision of Prof. M. Boscolo. His research interests are focused on biomass chemistry, mostly catalytic transformations of biomass into more added value products.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Jesús Eliecer Larrahondo is graduated in chemistry at Universidad del Valle , Colombia (1971), Ph.D. in chemistry at the Northeastern University, USA (1979). Professor of organic chemistry, phytochemistry and sucrochemistry. His was member of the committee of the international association of professionals in sugarcane and integrated sciences. He was a researcher and chief chemist at the Centro de Investigación en Caña de Azúcar (CENICAÑA), Colombia , for thirty years. He is a researcher and scientific advisor in the areas of phytochemistry, sucrochemistry and sugardairy processes.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Mauricio Boscolo
is graduated in Chemistry at University of São Paulo, Chemistry Institute of São Carlos (1994), M. Sc. (1996) and Ph.D (2001) in Analytical chemistry at same institution with a sandwich period of 1 year in the laboratory of Prof. Michele Aresta at the Università degli Studi di Bari , Italy (2000). He was postdoctoral fellow University of California, Santa Barbara (USA) under supervisor of Prof. Peter Ford on bioenergy related topics: new catalysts for lignin depolymerization by hydrogenolysis and supercritical catalytic hydrogenation. He was a Young FAPESP Research Fellow (2002–2004) developing a research project focused on the use of sucrose as a raw material for development of new chemical products (sucrochemistry). He is Associate Professor of the Department of Chemistry and

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Environmental Sciences of the São Paulo State University at Institute of Biosciences,

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Humanities and Exact Sciences (IBILCE). He was the first director of the Division of

sec.title: Orphanage

sec.p: to 2008. He coordinates the Laboratory of sucrochemistry and Analytical Chemistry of

sec.title: Orphanage
